11565||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Simple Equations - Contest of Newbies 2008</TITLE>
<META content="Simple Equations" name=description>
<META content=1036 name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#5000BF">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>
				Problem A: Simple Equations</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<P><font size=6>I</font>n this very first task, let us look at a boring mathematics problem. :-)

<P>We have three different integers, <i>x</i>, <i>y</i> and <i>z</i>, which satisfy the following three relations:

<ul>
  <li><i>x</i> + <i>y</i> + <i>z</i> = <i>A</i></li>
  <li><i>x</i><i>y</i><i>z</i> = <i>B</i></li>
  <li><i>x</i><sup>2</sup> + <i>y</i><sup>2</sup> + <i>z</i><sup>2</sup> = <i>C</i></li>
</ul>

<P>You are asked to <b>write a program</b> that solves for <i>x</i>, <i>y</i> and <i>z</i> for given values of <i>A</i>, <i>B</i> and <i>C</i>.

<P>For the <b>Extreme</b> version of this problem, please click <a href="11571.html">here</a>.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>The first line of the input file gives the number of test cases <b><i>N</i></b> (< 20). Each of the following <b><i>N</i></b> lines gives the values of <i>A</i>, <i>B</i> and <i>C</i> (1 &le; <i>A</i>, <i>B</i>, <i>C</i> &le; 10000).

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each test case, output the corresponding values of <i>x</i>, <i>y</i> and <i>z</i>. If there are many possible answers, choose the one with the least value of <i>x</i>. If there is a tie, output the one with the least value of <i>y</i>.
   If there is no solution, output the line "<b>No solution.</b>" instead.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
2
1 2 3
6 6 14
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
No solution.
1 2 3
</PRE>

<P><HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11566||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Let's Yum Cha! - Contest of Newbies 2008</TITLE>
<META content="Let's Yum Cha!" name=description>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>
<META http-equiv=Content-Style-Type content=text/css></HEAD>


<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#5000BF">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				B: Let's Yum Cha!</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00006000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Introduction</FONT></A></H2>

<p><i>Yum cha</i>, a term in Cantonese, literally meaning "<i>drinking tea</i>", refers to the custom of eating small servings of different foods (<i>dim sum</i>) while sipping Chinese tea. It is an integral part of the culinary culture of Guangdong and Hong Kong. For Cantonese people, to yum cha is a tradition on weekend mornings, and whole families gather to chat and eat dim sum and drink Chinese tea. The tea is important, for it helps digest the foods. In the past, people went to a teahouse to yum cha, but dim sum restaurants have been gaining overwhelming popularity recently.

<p><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11566a.gif"  align=right>

<p>Dim Sum literally means "<i>touch your heart</i>", which consists of a wide spectrum of choices, including combinations of meat, seafood, vegetables, as well as desserts and fruit.
   Dim sum can be cooked, <i>inter alia</i>, by steaming and deep-frying. The various items are usually served in a small steamer basket or on a small plate. The serving sizes are usually small and normally served as three or four pieces in one dish. Because of the small portions, people can try a wide variety of food.

<p>Some well-known dim sums are:
<li><b>Har gow</b>: A delicate steamed dumpling with shrimp filling and thin (almost translucent) wheat starch skin. It is one of my favourite dim sum.
<li><b>Siu mai</b>: A small steamed dumpling with pork inside a thin wheat flour wrapper. It is usually topped off with crab roe and mushroom.
<li><b>Char siu bau</b>: A bun with Cantonese barbeque-flavoured pork and onions inside. It is probably the most famous dim sum around the world.
<li><b>Sweet cream bun</b>: A steamed bun with milk custard filling. It is sweet and spongy.
<li><b>Spring roll</b>: Consists of sliced carrot, wood-ear fungus, and sometimes meat, rolled inside a thin flour skin and deep-fried. It is crispy and delicious.

<p>The picture on the right shows some of the dim sums mentioned above. Can you name them?

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00007000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Description</FONT></A></H2>

<p>Today you go to yum cha with <b>N</b> friends. You and your friends have agreed that everyone will pay the same amount of money (to within one dollar), and each and every one of you will pay at most <b>$x</b>.
   In the restaurant there are <b>K</b> kinds of dim sums to choose from. Every one of you has assigned an integer "<i>favour index</i>" to each dim sum, ranging from <b>0</b> to <b>10</b>.

<p>Now you are responsible for choosing what dim sums to order. You wanted to <b>maximize your total "favour value"</b> from dim sums you choose, but you will certainly get beaten by all your friends if you ignore their interest. Therefore, you shall <b>maximize the <i>mean</i> of the total favour value everyone gets</b>
   (computed using the formula <img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11566a.gif"  align=center>) instead.
   Note that even though we are considering the "mean favour value",  this does not imply that everyone can actually get a piece of every ordered item!! Anyway, since you are
   very good friends, you will certainly find some ways to share the food so that everyone is happy, right? :-)

<p>Since you would like to try more different kinds of dim sums, you shall NOT order more than <b>2</b> dishes of a same type of dim sum. Also, since you do not want to waste food, you shall NOT order more than <b>2(N+1)</b> dishes in total (i.e. 2 dishes for each of you).

<p>When computing the amount of money to be paid we shall NOT just add up the prices of the dim sums. We also need to take care of the following two charges:
<li><b>Tea charge</b>: everyone is charged <b>$T</b> for the tea provided.
<li><b>10% service charge</b>: you need to pay 10% of (Dim sum prices + Tea charge) as service charge. This value is to be rounded <b>up</b> to the nearest dollar.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>Input consists of no more than <b>25</b> test cases. Each case begins with four integers <b>N</b>, <b>x</b>, <b>T</b> and <b>K</b>, whose meanings have been explained above.
   Then comes <b>K</b> lines, each giving the information of one particular dim sum. The first integer is
   the price of the dim sum, followed by your favour index, then <b>N</b> integers which are the favour indices of your <b>N</b> friends.

<p>Input ends with a line with four zeros.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each case, your program should give the optimal mean favour value, correct to 2 decimal places. This value is always positive.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00003000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
3 10 5 2
6 7 5 6 9
10 9 10 10 8
0 0 0 0
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
16.00
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00005000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Constraints</FONT></A></H2>
<li>1 &le; <b>N</b> &le; 10
<li>1 &le; <b>x</b> &le; 100
<li>0 &le; <b>T</b> &le; 20
<li>1 &le; <b>K</b> &le; 100
<li>$1 &le; price of a dim sum &le; $100.

<P><HR><address>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei<br>Some references (including the photo) are taken from Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dim_Sum</address>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11567||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Moliu Number Generator - Contest of Newbies 2008</TITLE>
<META content="Moliu Number Generator" name=description>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>
</HEAD>

<BODY>
<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#5000BF">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				C: Moliu Number Generator</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<p>Let's play a number game. We start with <b><i>N</i></b> = 0, and we want to make <b><i>N</i></b> = a given integer <b><i>S</i></b>.

<p>Only <b>three</b> types of operations are allowed:<ol>
<li><font face="Courier New">INC</font> : increment <b><i>N</i></b> by 1, i.e. <b><i>N</i></b> <-- <b><i>N</i></b> + 1</li>
<li><font face="Courier New">DEC</font> : decrement <b><i>N</i></b> by 1, i.e. <b><i>N</i></b> <-- <b><i>N</i></b> - 1</li>
<li><font face="Courier New">DBL</font> : double <b><i>N</i></b>, i.e. <b><i>N</i></b> <-- 2 <b><i>N</i></b></li></ol>

<p>Of course we want to make <b><i>N</i></b> = <b><i>S</i></b> with the minimum number of operations. Consider an example: Let <b><i>S</i></b> = 7. Then
   only 5 steps are required, for instance:<ol>
<li><font face="Courier New">INC</font> : <b><i>N</i></b> = 0 + 1 = 1</li>
<li><font face="Courier New">INC</font> : <b><i>N</i></b> = 1 + 1 = 2</li>
<li><font face="Courier New">DBL</font> : <b><i>N</i></b> = 2 &times; 2 = 4</li>
<li><font face="Courier New">DBL</font> : <b><i>N</i></b> = 2 &times; 4 = 8</li>
<li><font face="Courier New">DEC</font> : <b><i>N</i></b> = 8 - 1 = 7  <-- DONE!!
</ol>



<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Input</FONT></A></H2>
<P>Input contains no more than <b>200</b> lines. Each line contains one integer <b><i>S</i></b> (0 &le; <b><i>S</i></b> &le; 2<sup>31</sup>). Input is terminated by EOF.


<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Output</FONT></A></H2>
<P>For each <b><i>S</i></b>, output the minimum number of operations required to make <b><i>N</i></b> = <b><i>S</i></b>. You may assume that <b><i>N</i></b> is of infinite precision, so NO overflow will ever occur.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00003000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>
<PRE>
7
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>
<PRE>
5
</PRE>

<P><HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei</I></ADDRESS></BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11568||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Pincer Attack!! - Contest of Newbies 2008</TITLE>
<META content="Pincer Attack!!" name=description>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>
<META http-equiv=Content-Style-Type content=text/css></HEAD>


<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#5000BF">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>Problem
				D: Pincer Attack!!</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<p>You wake up and find that you are trapped in a room. Luckily, you have a laptop computer with you, which may help you escape!

<p>You manage to get a map of the room, telling you where you are and where the exit is. You also
   know that there are two guarding robots inside the room. Normally they just <i>wander</i> around the
   room - they always try to move forward, but if they fail (for example, if they are facing a wall), they
   turn right until they can go forward. Before a robot moves, if you are in its direct east, south, west
   or north, and there are no walls separating you from it, it sees you. It then stops wandering, changes
   its direction and moves towards you. If you get out of its sight, it continues its normal wandering
   again.

<p>You get caught if you bump into a robot, or if a robot reaches you. <b>Write a program</b> that searches
   for a path leading you to the exit without getting caught.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT COLOR=#5000BF>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>Input consists of no more than <b>25</b> test cases. The first line of each case gives an integer <b><i>N</i></b> (4 &le; <b><i>N</i></b> &le; 10).
   This is followed by <b><i>N</i></b> lines, each with <b><i>N</i></b> characters, giving the map of the room.

<p>Key to the map:<ul>
     <li><b>X</b>: Your location.</li>
     <li><b>#</b>: A wall; an area that neither you nor the robots can travel to.</li>
     <li><b>&nbsp;</b> (a space): An area that both you and the robots can travel to.</li>
     <li><b>N</b>: A robot, facing north (upper side of the map).</li>
     <li><b>E</b>: A robot, facing east (right side of the map).</li>
     <li><b>S</b>: A robot, facing south.</li>
     <li><b>W</b>: A robot, facing west.</li>
     <li><b>T</b>: The exit, which is the only place that you can leave the room. Robots see it as a wall; they will not get out of the room.</li>
   </ul>

<p>There are always exactly two robots, and only one exit. The exit must appear on the boundary of the room.

<p>In every step, you move before the robots do. You can either move to the adjacent area in your east,
   south, west or north, or you can stay where you are. The two robots then move to their adjacent
   areas in the east, south, west or north, according to the rules specified above. They are thin enough
   to occupy the same position.

<p>Input ends with a line with only the integer 0.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT COLOR=#5000BF>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each case, your program should print a shortest path (in terms of the number of steps) that leads you to the exit, or the line "<b>You can't escape...</b>" otherwise.
   Use the characters <b>N</b>, <b>E</b>, <b>S</b>, <b>W</b> and <b>X</b> to denote moving to the north, east, south, west, or staying where you are respectively.
   If there are many solutions, print the lexicographically smallest one.


<P STYLE="page-break-before: always"><H2><A name=SECTION00003000000000000000><FONT COLOR=#5000BF>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
8
########
#S#    #
#E     #
# ##   #
###    T
###   ##
##  X ##
########
8
########
#S#    #
#E  #  #
T ##   #
###    #
###   ##
##  X ##
########
0
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT COLOR=#5000BF>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
ENNEE
You can't escape...
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT COLOR=#5000BF>Explanation</FONT></A></H2>

<p>The following shows how you escape for the first sample case, step by step. Note how robots change their direction while wandering:

<pre>
########  ########  ########  ########  ########  ########
#S#    #  # #    #  # #    #  # #    #  #N#    #  # #    #
#E     #  #SE    #  #  E   #  #N  E  #  #    E #  #S    E#
# ##   #  # ##   #  #S##   #  # ##   #  # ##   #  # ##   #
###    T  ###    T  ###    T  ###  X T  ###   XT  ###    X
###   ##  ###   ##  ###  X##  ###   ##  ###   ##  ###   ##
##  X ##  ##   X##  ##    ##  ##    ##  ##    ##  ##    ##
########  ########  ########  ########  ########  ########
</pre>

<P><HR><address>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei</address>
</BODY>
</HTML>
______________________________________________________
11569||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD>

<TITLE>Lovely Hint - First Contest of Newbies 2008</TITLE>
<META content="Lovely Hint" name=description>
<META content=1036 name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>
</HEAD>


<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#5000BF">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>
				Problem E: Lovely Hint</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>
<P>Jay and Kay decide to play a game. They write an English sentence on a piece of paper. The objective of the game is to pick out some of the written alphabets, rearrange them, and form the longest "lovely string".

<p>The definitions of "lovely string" are simple:

<ol>
 <li>It consists of upper case alphabets only, and it cannot be an empty string;</li>
 <li>All alphabets are assigned a value. For example, <b>A</b> is assigned to be 1, <b>B</b> is assigned to be 2...etc;</li>
 <li>For any substring of two alphabets, suppose the value of the first alphabet is <b>V<sub>1</sub></b> and that of the second alphabet is <b>V<sub>2</sub></b>.
     Then the following inequality must hold: <b>5 &times; V<sub>1</sub></b> &le; <b>4 &times; V<sub>2</sub></b>.
</ol>

<p>Jay asks you to help him. However, as he does not want to lose the fun of the game, he asks you to give him a hint only.
   <b>Write a program</b> to give the hint.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<P>The input contains an integer <b><i>N</i></b> (1 &le; <b><i>N</i></b> &le; 30). Each of the next <b><i>N</i></b> lines consists of a string <b>S</b>. The string can be as long as 250 characters, and will not
   contain lower case alphabets.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00002000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<P>For each case, print the length of the longest lovely string that can be formed using the alphabets, followed by the number of ways to achieve this length.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00003000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
2
HELLO.
I AM JAY.
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
4 1
4 2
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00005000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Explanation</FONT></A></H2>

<P>For the first case, we can get the lovely string <B>EHLO</B>.<BR>
   For the second case, we can get <B>AIMY</B> and <B>AJMY</B>.</p>

<HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Raymond Chun</I><BR>Task adapted from Question 2 of HKOI 2002, Junior Group</ADDRESS></BODY>
</HTML>
______________________________________________________
11570||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Sudoku without numbers? - Contest of Newbies 2008</TITLE>
<META content="Sudoku without numbers?" name=description>
<META content=1036 name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>

<style type="text/css">
PRE {font-face: Courier New; line-height: 75%}
</style>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#5000BF">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>
				Problem F: Sudoku without numbers?</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<P><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11570a.gif"  align=right>

<P><font size=6>O</font>n <i>Killer Sudoku Online</i> <sup>1</sup>, there is a very interesting Sudoku variant - <b>Greater Than Sudoku</b>.

<P>The right figure shows a Greater Than Sudoku puzzle. As you can see, there is absolutely no number to start with! There are only "greater-than signs" (>) between the cells.
   Beside usual Sudoku rules, there is an extra one: all greater-than signs must be satisfied, i.e. each of them must point from a larger number to a smaller one.

<P><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11570a.gif"  align="left">If there is no number given, then where shall we begin? Look at the partial puzzle shown in the left. Note that the 
   centre cell (coloured in blue) is the only cell in its "big square" with all its greater-than signs pointing inwards. Therefore, it must contain the smallest number, i.e. 1 (one).
   Together with the usual Sudoku skills and some new tricks, we can solve the puzzle completely.

<P>This sample puzzle is discussed in great detail in ReallyEvilCanine's blog <sup>2</sup>.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Problem</FONT></A></H2>

<P><b>Write a program</b> that solves Greater Than Sudoku puzzles. In short, for each puzzle, we need to complete the grid so that each row, column and 3 &times; 3 box contains every digit from 1 to 9 (inclusive),
      and each greater-than sign points from a larger digit to a smaller one.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>Input contains less than <b>10</b> test cases, each giving the greater-than signs in a Sudoku puzzle. Consecutive cases are separated by a blank line.

<p>The sample input below corresponds to the sample puzzle shown in the above figure. All input cases will follow the format of this sample exactly.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each test case, output the solution for the puzzle. Adjacent numbers in a row should be separated by a space, and consecutive sets of output should be separated by an empty line.

<p>You can be sure that there is one and only one solution for each input puzzle.

<P style="page-break-before: always"><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
 > <   < <   > < 
v ^ v v ^ v ^ ^ v
 < <   < >   < < 
v ^ v ^ v v ^ ^ v
 < <   < <   > > 
 < >   > >   < > 
v v ^ ^ v ^ ^ v v
 < >   > <   > > 
^ v v v ^ v v ^ v
 > <   < >   > > 
 < >   > >   > < 
v v v v ^ ^ ^ ^ ^
 > <   < <   < < 
^ ^ ^ ^ ^ v v v ^
 > >   < >   < < 

 > <   < <   > < 
v ^ v v ^ v ^ ^ v
 < <   < >   < < 
v ^ v ^ v v ^ ^ v
 < <   < <   > > 
 < >   > >   < > 
v v ^ ^ v ^ ^ v v
 < >   > <   > > 
^ v v v ^ v v ^ v
 > <   < >   > > 
 < >   > >   > < 
v v v v ^ ^ ^ ^ ^
 > <   < <   < < 
^ ^ ^ ^ ^ v v v ^
 > >   < >   < < 
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
5 3 9 4 6 8 2 1 7
2 4 8 1 9 7 3 5 6
1 6 7 2 3 5 9 8 4
6 8 1 7 4 2 5 9 3
3 7 5 9 1 6 8 4 2
9 2 4 5 8 3 7 6 1
7 9 6 8 2 1 4 3 5
4 1 2 3 5 9 6 7 8
8 5 3 6 7 4 1 2 9

5 3 9 4 6 8 2 1 7
2 4 8 1 9 7 3 5 6
1 6 7 2 3 5 9 8 4
6 8 1 7 4 2 5 9 3
3 7 5 9 1 6 8 4 2
9 2 4 5 8 3 7 6 1
7 9 6 8 2 1 4 3 5
4 1 2 3 5 9 6 7 8
8 5 3 6 7 4 1 2 9
</PRE>

<P><HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei
<br>Links:
<br><sup>1</sup> Killer Sudoku Online - http://www.killersudokuonline.com/
<br><sup>2</sup> A Day in the Life: Solving Greater Than Sudoku Puzzles - http://stuckinthecube.blogspot.com/2007/05/solving-greater-than-sudoku-puzzles.html
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>

11571||||||false||||||
<HTML>
<HEAD><TITLE>Simple Equations - Extreme!! - Contest of Newbies 2008</TITLE>
<META content="Simple Equations - Extreme!!" name=description>
<META content=1036 name=keywords>
<META content=document name=resource-type>
<META content=global name=distribution>
<META http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
<META content="MSHTML 6.00.2800.1106" name=GENERATOR>

</HEAD>

<BODY>

<TABLE WIDTH=100% BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=4 CELLSPACING=3 STYLE="page-break-inside: avoid">
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<COL WIDTH=256*>
	<THEAD>
		<TR VALIGN=BOTTOM>
			<TD WIDTH=100% BGCOLOR="#5000BF">
				<P><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><FONT FACE="Arial Black" SIZE=6>
				Problem G: Simple Equations - Extreme!!</FONT></P>
			</TD>
		</TR>
	</THEAD>
</TABLE>

<P><font size=6>T</font>his is an extreme version of Problem A of our contest. If your code solves this problem, it will also get "Accepted" for <a href="11565.html">Problem A</a>.

<P>Let us recall the scenario: we have three different integers, <i>x</i>, <i>y</i> and <i>z</i>, which satisfy the following three relations:

<ul>
  <li><i>x</i> + <i>y</i> + <i>z</i> = <i>A</i></li>
  <li><i>x</i><i>y</i><i>z</i> = <i>B</i></li>
  <li><i>x</i><sup>2</sup> + <i>y</i><sup>2</sup> + <i>z</i><sup>2</sup> = <i>C</i></li>
</ul>

<P>You are asked to <b>write a program</b> that solves for <i>x</i>, <i>y</i> and <i>z</i> for given values of <i>A</i>, <i>B</i> and <i>C</i>.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Input</FONT></A></H2>

<p>The first line of the input file gives the number of test cases <b><i>N</i></b> (< 250). Each of the following <b><i>N</i></b> lines gives the values of <i>A</i>, <i>B</i> and <i>C</i> (1 &le; <i>A</i>, <i>B</i>, <i>C</i> &le; 6 &times; 10<sup>18</sup> = 6000000000000000000).

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00001000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Output</FONT></A></H2>

<p>For each test case, output the corresponding values of <i>x</i>, <i>y</i> and <i>z</i>. If there are many possible answers, choose the one with the least value of <i>x</i>. If there is a tie, output the one with the least value of <i>y</i>.
   If there is no solution, output the line "<b>No solution.</b>" instead.

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Input</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
2
1 2 3
6 6 14
</PRE>

<P><H2><A name=SECTION00004000000000000000><FONT color=#5000BF>Sample Output</FONT></A></H2>

<PRE>
No solution.
1 2 3
</PRE>

<P><HR><ADDRESS><I>Problemsetter: Mak Yan Kei
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11572||||||false||||||
<html>
<h2>Problem A: Unique Snowflakes</h2>

Emily the entrepreneur has a cool business idea: packaging and selling
snowflakes. She has devised a machine that captures snowflakes as they
fall, and serializes them into a stream of snowflakes that flow, one by
one, into a package. Once the package is full, it is closed and
shipped to be sold.
<p>
The marketing motto for the company is "bags of uniqueness."
To live up to the motto, every snowflake in a package
must be different from the others. Unfortunately, this is
easier said than done, because in reality, many of the snowflakes
flowing through the machine are identical. Emily would like to
know the size of the largest possible package of unique snowflakes
that can be created. The machine can start filling the package
at any time, but once it starts, all snowflakes flowing from
the machine must go into the package until the package is completed
and sealed. The package can be completed and sealed before all of
the snowflakes have flowed out of the machine.
<h3>Input Specification</h3>
The first line of input contains one integer specifying the number of
test cases to follow. Each test case begins with a line containing
an integer <i>n</i>, the number of snowflakes processed by the machine.
The following <i>n</i> lines each contain an integer (in the range
0 to 10^9, inclusive) uniquely identifying
a snowflake. Two snowflakes are identified by the same integer if
and only if they are identical.
The input will contain no more than one million total snowflakes.

<h3>Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
1
5
1
2
3
2
1
</pre>

<h3>Output Specification</h3>
For each test case output a line containing single integer, the maximum
number of unique snowflakes that can be in a package.

<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
3
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Ond&#345;ej Lhot&aacute;k, Richard Peng</i>
</html>

______________________________________________________
11573||||||false||||||
<html>
<h2>Problem B: Ocean Currents</h2>

For a boat on a large body of water, strong currents can be dangerous,
but with careful planning, they can be harnessed to help the boat
reach its destination. Your job is to help in that planning.
<p>
At each location, the current flows in some direction. The captain
can choose to either go with the flow of the current, using no energy,
or to move one square in any other direction, at the cost of one energy unit.
The boat always moves in one of the following eight directions:
north, south, east, west, northeast, northwest, southeast, southwest.
The boat cannot leave the boundary of the lake.
You are to help him devise a strategy to reach the destination with
the minimum energy consumption.

<h3>Input Specification</h3>

The lake is represented as a rectangular grid. The first line
of input contains two integers <i>r</i> and <i>c</i>, the
number of rows and columns in the grid. The grid has no more than
1000 rows and no more than 1000 columns. Each of the following
<i>r</i> lines contains exactly <i>c</i> characters,
each a digit from 0 to 7 inclusive. The character 0 means the
current flows north (i.e. up in the grid, in the direction of decreasing
row number), 1 means it flows
northeast, 2 means east (i.e. in the direction of increasing column number), 3 means southeast, and so on in a clockwise
manner:
<pre>
7 0 1
 \|/
6-*-2
 /|\
5 4 3
</pre>

The line after the grid contains a single integer <i>n</i>,
the number of trips to be made, which is at most 50. Each of the following
<i>n</i> lines describes a trip using four integers
<i>rs</i>, <i>cs</i>, <i>rd</i>, <i>cd</i>, giving
the row and column of the starting point and the destination
of the trip. Rows and columns are numbered starting with 1.

<h3>Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
5 5
04125
03355
64734
72377
02062
3
4 2 4 2
4 5 1 4
5 3 3 4
</pre>

<h3>Output Specification</h3>

For each trip, output a line containing a single integer,
the minimum number of energy units needed to get from the
starting point to the destination.

<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
0
2
1
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Ond&#345;ej Lhot&aacute;k, Richard Peng</i>
</html>

______________________________________________________
11574||||||false||||||
<html>
<h2>Problem C: Colliding Traffic</h2>

For a boat on a small, constrained body of water, other traffic can be a
major hazard. The more traffic there is in the same area, the higher
the risk of a collision.
<p>
Your job is to monitor traffic and help detect likely collisions
before they occur. You have sensors to detect the position,
direction, and speed of each boat. Assuming the direction and
speed remain constant, your task is to determine whether any of
the boats will collide. Two boats are considered to collide if
they come within a given distance of each other.
<h3>Input Specification</h3>

The first line of input contains a single integer <i>c</i>, the number
of test cases to follow. Each test case starts with a line
containing two numbers, <i>n</i>, the number of boats, and
<i>r</i>, the collision distance. Two boats are considered
to collide if they come within <i>r</i> metres of each other.
There will be no more than 1000 boats.
Each boat is identified by a line containing four numbers
<i>x</i>, <i>y</i>, <i>d</i>, <i>s</i>.
The numbers <i>x</i> and <i>y</i> give the current position of the
boat as a distance east and north, respectively, from a common
origin, and will be between -1000 and 1000, inclusive. The lake is small enough that we can model it as a flat
surface. The number <i>d</i> gives the direction in which the
boat is heading in degrees clockwise from north (so east is 90 degrees).
The number <i>s</i> gives the speed of the boat in metres per second,
and will be between 0.001 and 1000.
Note that <i>r</i>, <i>x</i>, <i>y</i>, <i>d</i>, and <i>s</i> are
not necessarily integers.
The input data will be such that the answer will not change if any of 
the numbers <i>x</i>, <i>y</i>, <i>d</i> and <i>s</i> are
changed by 10^-6 or less.
If any two boats are within <i>r</i> metres of each other in their
initial position, they are already collided, so you should output
0 for that case.

<h3>Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
2
2 5
0 0 90 1
10 10 180 1
2 10
0 0 0 0
8 8 270 1
</pre>

<h3>Output Specification</h3>

For each test case, output a line containing a single integer, the
number of seconds, rounded to the nearest second, before any of the
boats come within <i>r</i> metres of each other.
If none of the boats ever collide, output the line:
<pre>
No collision.
</pre>

<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
6
2
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Ond&#345;ej Lhot&aacute;k, Richard Peng</i>
</html>

______________________________________________________
11575||||||false||||||
<html>
    <h2>Problem D: Zerg Rush!!!</h2>


A typical strategy in the game Starcraft is to mass up large amounts
of low-tier units such as Zerglings, then throw them at your opponent
and laugh maniacally as they overwhelm any opposition. However, when
both players opt for the same strategy, the result can often
become...quick, brutal and messy. Sadly, the game only allows for up
to 400 Zerglings per player. In this problem, however, you will simulate
games that could have more than 400 Zerglings.
<p>
The map on which Zerg rushes occur is represented by a NxN grid. Each
Zergling occupies a grid square and no two Zerglings ever occupy
the same grid square. Each Zergling has a certain number of hit points which
starts off as 35. Its attack value is 5 plus the attack upgrade
of the player that controls it. When one Zergling attacks another, the
damage incurred equals to the attack value of the attacking Zergling
minus the armour upgrade of the player that owns the Zergling being
attacked. The number of hit points of the Zergling that is attacked
is reduced by the amount of the damage.
<p>
Due to the inability of both players to manage their huge horde of
Zerglings, the Zerglings make their decisions each turn using
the following algorithm (Zerglings are not the brightest creatures, as you will
see):
<ul>

<li>If there is an opponent Zergling in one of the 8 horizontally,
vertically, or diagonally adjacent grid squares, the Zergling will attack it.
A Zergling attacks at most one opponent each turn; see below for the
tie-breaking rules.

<li>Otherwise, if the other player has at least one Zergling remaining
on the map, the Zergling will move to the horizontally, vertically,
or diagonally adjacent square that is closest to the opponent's closest
Zergling in terms of
Manhattan distance.
When more than one adjacent square is closest, the tie-breaking
rules below are used.
The Manhattan distance between two points is the sum of the
differences in the <i>x</i> and <i>y</i> coordinates of the
points.
</ul>

When the above rules could cause the Zergling to attack in more
than one direction, or to move in more than one direction, the
following tie-breaking rule is used.
The
Zergling will prefer the first direction starting with north going
clockwise. That is, the directions in order of preference are north,
northeast, east, southeast, etc.
<p>

Once all Zerglings have made their decisions, all the attacks are conducted simultaneously and
all the Zerglings with 0 or fewer hit points are marked as dead and removed
from the map. Then all the movements of the Zerglings that didn't
attack are conducted simultaneously. If the square to which a Zergling
is moving is occupied by another Zergling that is not moving away in
this turn, then the Zergling does not move.
If two or more Zerglings try to move to the same grid square,
then the Zergling
in the northernmost row
has the right of
way and the other Zergling remains stationary. If there are
multiple Zerglings in the northernmost row trying to move to the same
grid square, then of these, the westernmost Zergling moves and
the others remain stationary.
Zerglings also have a
remarkable regeneration rate. After each turn, all the Zerglings that
are still alive and have less than 35 hitpoints will regain one hit
point.
<p>
<h3>Input Specification</h3>

The input file contains a number of test cases, ended by a case with
<i>N</i>=0. Each case begins with <i>N</i> between 2 and 150, followed by 2 pairs of
2 integers between 0 and 3, the attack and armour upgrades of the first
player, followed by the attack and armour upgrades of the second
player.
This is followed by the initial game map, where
'<tt>.</tt>' denotes an empty square, '<tt>1</tt>' a Zergling belonging to the first
player and '<tt>2</tt>' a Zergling belonging to the second player.
On the map, north is up (i.e. towards the first row) and west is left
(i.e. towards the first column).
Finally, the
test case provides the number <i>t</i> of turns for which the Zerg rush is to be
simulated,
which is an integer between 0 and 400, inclusive.

<h3>Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
2
0 0
0 0
1.
..
0
2
0 0
0 0
1.
.2
100
0
</pre>

<h3>Output Specification</h3>

For each input case, output the map after <i>t</i> turns in the same format
as above.  Print one empty line between the output for consecutive
test cases.

<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
1.
..

..
..
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Richard Peng, Ond&#345;ej Lhot&aacute;k</i>
</html>

______________________________________________________
11576||||||false||||||
<html>
<h2>Problem E: Scrolling Sign</h2>

Electric scrolling signs are often used for advertising.
A given sign displays exactly <i>k</i> characters. When the
sign is switched on, all of the character positions are
initially empty (showing spaces). In each time interval,
all of the characters on the sign are shifted to the left
by one position, and a new character is added at the right-most
position. The character that was in the left-most position
moves off the sign.
<p>
For certain sequences of words, it is possible to reuse characters
from one word to form a subsequent word. For example, on a sign
with three character positions, the sign can display the message
CAT ATE TED by scrolling in the five characters CATED.
<p>
The advertiser has a specific message to show using the sign.
The faster the message is displayed, the more people will be
able to see the whole message. Therefore, your job is to find
a way to display all the words of the message by scrolling in
the smallest number of letters. In between showing the words
of the message, the sign may display other words that are not
considered part of the message. However, the words of the message 
must be shown in the order in which they are given. If a word
appears two or more times consecutively in the message, the
sign only needs to show it once.
<h3>Input Specification</h3>

The first line of input contains a single integer <i>n</i>, the number
of test cases to follow. Each test case starts with a line
containing a two integers, <i>k</i>, the number of character positions on
the sign, and <i>w</i>, the number of words in the message.
Each of the two integers is between 1 and 100, inclusive.
The following <i>w</i> lines each contain a word of the message comprising
exactly <i>k</i> uppercase letters.

<h3>Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
2
3 2
CAT
TED
3 3
CAT
ATE
TEA
</pre>

<h3>Output Specification</h3>

For each test case, output a line containing a single integer, the
minimum number of letters that must be scrolled into the sign
so that it displays all the words of the message.

<h3>Output for Sample Input</h3>

<pre>
5
5
</pre>
<hr>
<i>Ond&#345;ej Lhot&aacute;k, Richard Peng</i>
</html>

______________________________________________________
11577||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem A: Letter Frequency</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Sumudu Fernando">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem A: Letter Frequency</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11577.png"  alt="A weird keyboard" width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>In this problem we are interested in the frequency of letters in a
given line of text. Specifically, we want to know the most frequently
occurring letter(s) in the text, ignoring case (to be clear, "letters"
refers precisely to the 26 letters of the alphabet).
</p><p>Input begins with the number of test cases on its own line.
Each test case consists of a single
line of text. The line may contain non-letter characters, but is
guaranteed to contain at least one letter and less than 200 characters
in total.
</p><p>For each test case, output a line containing the most
frequently occurring letter(s) from the text in lowercase (if there are
ties, output
all such letters in alphabetical order).
</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>1
Computers account for only 5% of the country's commercial electricity consumption.
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>co
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Sumudu Fernando</em>

</body></html>

11578||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem B: Situp Benches</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Kevin Waugh">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem B: Situp Benches</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11578.png"  alt="Joe Six-Pack" width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>The gym at the University of Alberta has two identical sit up benches
that are side by side.  Each of these benches can be inclined in 10
degree increments between 10 degrees and 50 degrees inclusive
depending on the level of difficulty the user desires.  At the
end of each day the gym staff adjust the incline of each machine to be
10 degrees.  This means at the start of each day both machines have a
10 degree incline.

</p><p>Every time someone uses a bench it incurs some wear and tear that
amounts to 15 cents in maintenance costs.  Additionally, every time a
bench has its incline changed it incurs wear and tear that amounts to
the number of degrees the bench was adjusted, in cents.
For example, if someone moves the bench from a 40 degree
incline to a 20 degree incline then 20 cents of maintenance must be
done.

</p><p>The gym staff have recently required students to sign up for the situp
benches the day before.  When a student signs up they give the time at
which they would like to use the machine and the incline they will use
it at.  No more than two students can sign up to use a bench at the
same time.

</p><p>Prior to opening the gym for the day, the gym staff would like to have
a list assigning students to each of the situp benches and they would
like the assignment to minimize the total maintenance cost for the
day.  They have asked you to write a program to make this list.

</p><p>Input begins with the number of test cases on its own line.
Each test case begins with the number <em>n</em> (1 â¤ <em>n</em> â¤ 10000), the
number of students who have signed up to use the benches on the
following day.  Following are <em>n</em> lines, each consisting of two
numbers: <em>time_slot</em> and <em>incline</em>.
<em>time_slot</em> is a number that specifies when a student will arrive
at the machine, while <em>incline</em> specifies the angle to which they
will adjust the situp bench.  Two students in the same <em>time_slot</em> arrive at the
benches at the same time, and lower <em>time_slot</em>s occur before
higher <em>time_slot</em>s.  <em>time_slot</em>s are numbered between 0 and 20000, and
<i>incline</i> is one of 10, 20, 30, 40 or 50 depending on the
student's preference.

</p><p>For each test case, output a line containing the total maintenance cost (in cents) for the day
followed by <em>n</em> lines (one for each student, in the order given on input) containing
either a 1 or a 2 depending on which bench you have assigned them
to.  Any assignment that minimizes the total maintenance cost for the
day is acceptable.

</p><h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>1
3
2 40
2 50
1 40
</pre>

<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>185
1
2
1
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Kevin Waugh</em>

</body></html>

	<title>Problem C: Triangle Trouble</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Sumudu Fernando">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem C: Triangle Trouble</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11579.png"  alt="These are also limited edition triangles" width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>There is trouble at the triangle factory. The triangle assembler has
gone down, so all that has been produced for the day is
a bunch of triangle sides. To make the best of this situation, it has
been decided to create the triangle with the largest possible
area from the available sides, and sell it as a limited edition
triangle.
</p><p>You have been hired to write a program that will determine the area of the limited edition triangle.

</p><p>Input begins with the number of test cases on its own line.  Each test case begins with a
positive integer <em>N</em> (3 â¤ <em>N</em> â¤ 10,000), followed by <em>N</em> positive real numbers <em>s<sub>i</sub></em> representing the lengths of the available triangle sides (0 &lt; <em>s<sub>i</sub></em> â¤ 100,000).  A single test case may be spread out over several consecutive lines of the input.

</p><p>For each test case, output a line containing the largest
possible area of a triangle built using three of the given sides (as a
real number
rounded to 2 decimal places). If it is not possible to construct any
triangles then output "0.00" (quotes for clarity).
</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>2
4 3.0 4.0 5.0 100.0
3 1.0 2.0 4.0
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>6.00
0.00
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Sumudu Fernando</em>

</body></html>

11580||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem D: Finding the Transmitter</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Sumudu Fernando">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem D: Finding the Transmitter</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11580a.png"  alt="Finding the angle to the transmitter" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Triangulation is an ancient technique for locating points in a
coordinate system based on the measurement of angles, as opposed to the
measurement
of distances. This makes it especially useful for precisely locating
points that are not practically reachable, as long as one can determine
what direction they are in.
</p><p>In this problem, you are trying to locate a radio transmitter somewhere on Earth, using angle measurements 
from two known points. At each of
the given points, the angle to the transmitter is determined by the angle between a shortest path to the North Pole 
and a shortest path
to the transmitter, measured clockwise looking from above the surface of the earth.
Paths are constrained to the surface of the earth, and the earth's surface is assumed to be a perfect sphere.

</p><p>It is guaranteed that neither of the given points is at the
North Pole or the South Pole (to avoid ambiguity in angle
measurements), and
one may assume that the transmitter is located at a third (distinct)
point which is uniquely locatable using the measurements.
</p><p>Points on the Earth are denoted using latitude and longitude
notation in decimal degrees (rounded to two decimal places).
See the figures for an explanation of the latitude/longitude system.
Note that for this problem, the equator's latitude must be reported as
"0.00 N",
while the longitude is written "0.00 W" at the Prime Meridian and
"180.00 W" at the International Date Line. Furthermore, the longitude
at the Poles
should be given as "0.00 W". In other words, where ambiguity exists,
the use of "0.00" and/or "N/W" is dictated.
</p><p>Input begins with the number of test cases on its own line.
Each test case consists of two
lines, each containing the latitude and longitude of a point followed
by the angle to the transmitter (all of these are given as real
numbers).
</p><p>For each test case, output a line containing the latitude and
longitude of the transmitter, rounded to two decimal places in decimal
degrees.
</p><p align="center"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11580a.png"  alt="How latitude works"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11580a.png"  alt="How longitude works">

</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>1
0.00 N 45.00 E 180.00
0.00 N 45.00 W 180.00
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>90.00 S 0.00 W
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Sumudu Fernando</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11581||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem E: Grid Successors</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Zachary Friggstad">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem E: Grid Successors</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11581.png"  alt="Not a grid of numbers" width="200" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Consider a 3 x 3 grid of numbers <em>g</em> where each cell contains either a 0 or a 1.
We define a function <em>f</em> that transforms such a grid: each cell of the
grid <em>f(g)</em> is the sum (modulo 2) of its adjacent cells in <em>g</em>
(two cells are considered adjacent if and only if they share a common side).

</p><p>Furthermore, we define <em>f&nbsp;<sup>(i)</sup>(g)</em> recursively
as <em>f&nbsp;<sup>(0)</sup>(g) = g</em> and
<em>f&nbsp;<sup>(i+1)</sup>(g) &nbsp;=&nbsp; f(f&nbsp;<sup>(i)</sup>(g))</em>
(where <em>i &nbsp;â¥&nbsp; 0</em>).
Finally, for any grid <em>h</em>, let <em>k<sub>g</sub>(h)</em> be the number of
indices <em>i</em> such that <em>h = f&nbsp;<sup>(i)</sup>(g)</em> 
(we may have <em>k<sub>g</sub>(h) = â</em>).
Given a grid <em>g</em>, your task is to compute the greatest index <em>i</em>
such that <em>k<sub>g</sub>(f&nbsp;<sup>(i)</sup>(g))</em> is finite.

</p><p>Input begins with the number of test cases on its own line.
Each case consists of a blank line followed by three lines of three characters, each either <code>1</code> or <code>0</code>.
The <em>j</em>'th character
of the <em>i</em>'th row of the test case is the value in the <em>j</em>'th cell
of the <em>i</em>'th row of the grid <em>g</em>.

</p><p>For each test case, output the greatest index <em>i</em> such that
<em>k<sub>g</sub>(f&nbsp;<sup>(i)</sup>(g))</em> is finite.
If there is no such index, output -1.

</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>3

111
100
001

101
000
101

000
000
000
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>3
0
-1
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Babak Behsaz and Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

11582||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem F: Colossal Fibonacci Numbers!</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Zachary Friggstad">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem F: Colossal Fibonacci Numbers!</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11582.png"  alt="Oooh...pretty" width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>The <em>i</em>'th Fibonacci number <em>f&nbsp;(i)</em> is recursively defined in the following way:
</p><ul>
<li> <em>f&nbsp;(0) = 0</em> and <em>f&nbsp;(1) = 1</em>
</li><li> <em>f&nbsp;(i+2) = f&nbsp;(i+1) + f&nbsp;(i)</em> &nbsp;for every <em>i&nbsp;â¥&nbsp;0</em>
</li></ul>

<p>Your task is to compute some values of this sequence.

</p><p>Input begins with an integer <em>t</em>&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;10,000, the number of test cases.
Each test case consists of three integers <em>a,b,n</em> where 0&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;<em>a,b</em>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;2<sup>64</sup>
(<em>a</em> and <em>b</em> will not both be zero)
and 1&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;<em>n</em>&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;1000.

</p><p>For each test case, output a single line
containing the remainder of <em>f&nbsp;(a<sup>b</sup>)</em> upon division by <em>n</em>.

</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>3
1 1 2
2 3 1000
18446744073709551615 18446744073709551615 1000
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>1
21
250
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

11583||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem G: Alien DNA</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Zachary Friggstad">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem G: Alien DNA</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11583.png"  alt="Unfortunately, this is not a Magic Eye" width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Alien DNA is more complicated than human DNA.  For example, rather than
viewing an alien DNA strand as a sequence of base pairs, it can be viewed as a sequence
of base sets.  A base set is, simply put, a string of lowercase letters where
each letter represents a different base.  Note that human
DNA is also a sequence of base sets, except a base set is simply a pairing of <code>a</code>
with <code>t</code> or <code>c</code> with <code>g</code>.

</p><p>Since alien DNA is more complicated than human DNA, the algorithms used in
alien bioinformatics are also much more complicated.
However, you have only been working at AlienBioTechNextGenCorp for three days
and are not yet trusted enough to handle the complicated tasks.

</p><p>Your first job is simple.
You must develop software to cut a strand of alien DNA into as few segments
as possible.  The only constraint is that base sets of a given segment must
share at least one common base.

</p><p>Input begins with an integer <em>t</em>&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;100, the number of test cases
to be processed.
Each test case begins with a single value <em>n</em> (1&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;<em>n</em>&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;10,000)
representing the length of the alien DNA strand.  Each of the <em>n</em> following lines consists
of a single string of lowercase letters representing a base set.  Each
string will contain at least one character, and no repeated characters.
The base sets are given in the input in the same order they appear on the DNA strand.

</p><p>For each test case, output the minimum number of cuts required to
partition the strand into segments that share a common base.

</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>2
5
as
sd
df
fg
gh
3
plum
orange
plum
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>2
2
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Babak Behsaz and Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

11584||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem H: Partitioning by Palindromes</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Kevin Waugh">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem H: Partitioning by Palindromes</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11584.png"  alt="Can you read upside-down?" width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>We say a sequence of characters is a <em>palindrome</em> if it is the same written
forwards and backwards.  For example, 'racecar' is a palindrome, but 
'fastcar' is not.

</p><p>A <em>partition</em> of a sequence of characters is a list of
one or more disjoint 
non-empty groups of consecutive characters whose concatenation yields the 
initial sequence.  For example, ('race', 'car') is a partition of 'racecar'
into two groups.

</p><p>Given a sequence of characters, we can always create a partition of these
characters such that each group in the partition is a palindrome!  Given 
this observation it is natural to ask: what is the minimum number of groups
needed for a given string such that every group is a palindrome?

</p><p>For example:
</p><ul>
<li> 'racecar' is already a palindrome, therefore it can be partitioned into one group.
</li><li> 'fastcar' does not contain any non-trivial palindromes, so it must be partitioned as ('f', 'a', 's', 't', 'c', 'a', 'r').
</li><li> 'aaadbccb' can be partitioned as ('aaa', 'd', 'bccb').
</li></ul>

<p>Input begins with the number <em>n</em> of test cases.  Each test case consists of a single line of
between 1 and 1000 lowercase letters, with no whitespace within.

</p><p>For each test case, output a line containing the minimum 
number of groups required to partition the input into groups of palindromes.

</p><h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>3
racecar
fastcar
aaadbccb
</pre>

<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>1
7
3
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Kevin Waugh</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11585||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem I: Nurikabe</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Zachary Friggstad">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem I: Nurikabe</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11585a.png"  alt="At least it's not a sudoku problem" width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>The puzzle Nurikabe is played on a grid.  Initially, each grid space is either
blank or contains a single number.  The goal is to shade in some of the blank
spaces to satisfy the following constraints:
</p><ul>
<li> Any two shaded spaces are connected
by some sequence of adjacent shaded spaces.
Two spaces are called adjacent if they share a side.
</li><li> For each of the unshaded spaces <em>b</em>, let <em>W<sub>b</sub></em> be the collection
of all unshaded spaces that can be reached from <em>b</em> by a sequence of adjacent unshaded
spaces.  Then, <em>W<sub>b</sub></em> contains exactly one numbered space and that number
is exactly the number of spaces in <em>W<sub>b</sub></em>.
</li><li> For any unshaded space <em>b</em>, there is a sequence of unshaded spaces
starting at <em>b</em> and ending at a space on the edge of the grid
where consecutive spaces in this sequence share a side or a corner.
</li><li> Finally, in every 2 x 2 subsquare there is at least one unshaded space.
</li></ul>

<p>The image shows an example of a Nurikabe puzzle and its solution.  Take care to verify all
four constraints are satisfied in the solution.  To help you understand the third constraint,
note that the middle cell containing the number 1 can reach the edge of the grid since
it shares a corner with a group of unshaded spaces containing the number 2.

</p><p align="center"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11585a.png"  alt="Example Nurikabe">

</p><p>It is known that the problem of determining if a Nurikabe grid can be shaded to satisfy
the constraints is NP-complete.  Your task is much easier.  Given an initial grid and
a proposed shading, determine if the shading satisfies the constraints of the Nurikabe puzzle.

</p><p>Input begins with a single integer <em>t</em> that indicates
the number of grids to verify.
The first line of each case contains three integers <em>r,c,d</em>
where the grid has <em>r</em> rows and <em>c</em> columns (1&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;<em>r,c</em>&nbsp;â¤&nbsp;100).
Then, <em>d</em>
lines follow, each containing three integers <em>r',c',n</em>
meaning the grid cell at location (<em>r',c'</em>) contains the positive number <em>n</em>.
The upper-left grid space has coordinates (0,0), no space receives more
than one number, and no two numbered grid spaces will share an edge.
Finally, the shading data is specified 
by <em>r</em> strings of <em>c</em> characters each (one string per line).
The <em>j</em>'th character in the <em>i</em>'th row
of the shading data is '#' if the cell with coordinates (<em>i,j</em>) is shaded and '.'
if that cell is not shaded.
Each test case is preceded by a blank line.

</p><p>For each input case, output a line containing either <code>solved</code>
or <code>not solved</code> to indicate whether or not
the shading represents a solution to the puzzle.

</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>5

5 5 6
0 0 3
0 2 1
0 4 2
2 2 1
3 4 2
4 0 2
.#.#.
.###.
.#.##
###..
..###

5 5 6
0 0 3
0 2 1
0 4 2
2 2 1
3 4 3
4 0 2
.#.#.
.###.
.#.##
####.
..#..

2 3 1
0 0 2
.##
.##

2 2 1
0 0 1
..
##

2 2 2
0 0 1
1 1 1
.#
#.
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>solved
not solved
not solved
not solved
not solved
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11586||||||false||||||
ï»¿<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem J: Train Tracks</title>
	<meta name="author" content="Martin MÃ¼ller">
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem J: Train Tracks</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/p11586.png"  alt="Some wooden pieces" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Andy loves his set of wooden trains and railroad tracks. 
Each day, Daddy has to build a new track for him.
The tracks he likes best form a simple loop with no branches or dead ends,
so he can run his trains around and around for hours until it is time for
the big crash that destroys the whole construction.

</p><p>So here is the question: 
Given a set of track pieces, can you form a simple loop with them,
while using up all the pieces?

</p><p>Each piece of track is described by the connectors at both ends. 
A standard piece has one "male" and one "female" connector. 
But there are also track pieces with two male or two female connectors, 
as shown in the front right of the picture.

</p><p>To fit together, each male connector must be connected to a female connector. 
Unlike real wooden tracks, our pieces are assumed to be flexible, 
so their length or shape is not an issue here.
However, you may not connect the two ends of the same piece together. 

</p><p>Input begins with the number of test cases.
Each following line contains one test case. 
Each test case consists of a list of between 1 and 50 (inclusive) train track pieces.
A piece is described by two code letters: M for male or F for female connector.
Pieces are separated by space characters.

</p><p>For each test case, output a line containing either <code>LOOP</code> or <code>NO LOOP</code>
to indicate whether or not all the pieces can be joined into a single loop.

</p><h3>Sample input</h3>
<pre>4
MF MF
FM FF MF MM
MM FF
MF MF MF MF FF
</pre>

<h3>Sample output</h3>
<pre>LOOP
LOOP
LOOP
NO LOOP
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Martin MÃ¼ller</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<div align=center>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .25pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:480;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .25pt solid windowtext;mso-border-insidev:.25pt solid windowtext'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=97 valign=top style='width:73.1pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .25pt;background:#E6E6E6;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:143.25pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:60.0pt;font-family:
  Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>A<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=446 valign=top style='width:4.65in;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .25pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .25pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:143.25pt'><span
  style='font-size:28.0pt;font-family:Impact;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>Brick
  Game<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:143.25pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:Arial;
  mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>Input:</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial;
  mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'> Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:143.25pt'><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:Arial;
  mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>Output:</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial;
  mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'> Standard Output<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=99 valign=top style='width:74.5pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .25pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .25pt;background:#E0E0E0;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:143.25pt'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype
   id="_x0000_t75" coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t"
   path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe" filled="f" stroked="f">
   <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
   <v:formulas>
    <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
   </v:formulas>
   <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
   <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
  </v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" alt="  style='width:64.5pt;
   height:63.75pt'>
   <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/acmlogo.png"  o:href="http://www.informatik.uni-ulm.de/acm/images/acmlogo.gif"/>
  </v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=86 height=85
  src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/acmlogo.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>SH</b> and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>TR</b> are playing
the famous <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>brick game</i>. For those who arent
aware of the rules of this illustrious game, here goes a brief description: </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:10.0pt;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in;line-height:115%;
mso-list:l0 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-family:Wingdings;
mso-fareast-font-family:Wingdings;mso-bidi-font-family:Wingdings'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>§<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="Picture_x0020_6"
 o:spid="_x0000_s1044" type="#_x0000_t75" alt="http://chieftainwalk.org/Assets/Bricks.jpg"
 style='position:absolute;left:0;text-align:left;margin-left:0;margin-top:1.3pt;
 width:146.7pt;height:198.75pt;z-index:1;visibility:visible;
 mso-position-horizontal:left'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/acmlogo.png"  o:title="Bricks"/>
 <w:wrap type="square"/>
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=196 height=265
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/115/acmlogo.png"  align=left hspace=12
alt="http://chieftainwalk.org/Assets/Bricks.jpg" v:shapes="Picture_x0020_6"><![endif]>Its
a two player game in which there is initially some number of bricks on a table.
</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:10.0pt;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in;line-height:115%;
mso-list:l0 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-family:Wingdings;
mso-fareast-font-family:Wingdings;mso-bidi-font-family:Wingdings'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>§<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]>Each player moves alternately. Player <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>1</b> makes the first move. In our case, <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>SH</b> is player <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>1</b>. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:10.0pt;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in;line-height:115%;
mso-list:l0 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-family:Wingdings;
mso-fareast-font-family:Wingdings;mso-bidi-font-family:Wingdings'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>§<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]>In each move, a player removes some number of
bricks from the table. The number of bricks that can be removed in a single
move must be a member of a certain set of <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>K</b>
numbers. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:10.0pt;
margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.25in;line-height:115%;
mso-list:l0 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-family:Wingdings;
mso-fareast-font-family:Wingdings;mso-bidi-font-family:Wingdings'><span
style='mso-list:Ignore'>§<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]>The player to remove the last brick wins the
game. If a player finds that he cant make any valid move in his turn, he loses
the game.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Both <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>SH</b> and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>TR</b> have recently
spent a lot of time working out at the gym. They have acquired enough strength
to lift a lot of bricks in a single move. However, the bricks that they are
playing with are quite heavy and in a single move a player can remove at most
20 bricks from the table.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>The set, thus, can be represented as <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>S</b> = {<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:
"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>0</span></b><span
style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'> &lt; <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>A<sub>1</sub></b> &lt; <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>A<sub>2</sub></b> &lt; <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>A<sub>3</sub></b>
&lt; 
 &lt; <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>A<sub>K-1</sub></b> &lt; <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>A<sub>K</sub></b> &lt; <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>21</b></span>}</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>You will be given a string
consisting of <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>N</b> characters. The <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>i<sup>t</sup></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><sup><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>h</span></sup></b>(<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>1 &#8804; i &#8804; N</b>) character
represents the state if there were initially <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>i</span></b>
bricks. A state is symbolized by <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>L</b>
or <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>W</b> and they represent losing
states and winning states, respectively. The states are calculated based on the
fact that both of them play perfectly. For example, if the 10<sup>th</sup>
character of the given string is <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>L</b>,
then no matter what strategy <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>SH</b>
follows he will always end up losing if they start with 10 bricks.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Given the states, your job is to
minimize the cardinality of the set <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>S</b>;
that is you have to minimize the value of <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>K</b>.
Note that the set cannot be empty. You will also need to find the members of
the set <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>S</b>. In case there are
multiple sets with the same minimum cardinality that satisfies the given
states, you have to select the one that comes lexicographically earliest. Set <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>S1</b> will come earlier than <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>S2,</b> if in the first differing element <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>S1</b>s corresponding value has a lesser
magnitude.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Example: (1, 3, 6) will come
before (1, 4, 5).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h5 style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>Input</span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Arial Unicode MS"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h5>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The first line of input is an
integer <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>T</b>(<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>T</b>&lt;<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>201</b>) that indicates
the number of test cases. Each of the next <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>T</b>
lines contains a string consisting of characters <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>L</b> and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>W</b> only. The length
of a string is at most <b>100</b>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h4><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt'>Output <o:p></o:p></span></span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For each case, output the case
number first. Then output the set of <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>K</b>
elements in ascending order based on the description given above. It is
guaranteed that there will be at least 1 set of numbers that will yield the
given states in the input.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h1 align=left style='text-align:left'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
font-style:normal'>Sample Input<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                              </span>Output for Sample
Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:
 solid windowtext .5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=313 valign=top style='width:234.9pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
  normal'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>3<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
  normal'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>WWLWWL<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
  normal'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>WWWW<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
  normal'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>WLW</span><o:p></o:p></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=336 valign=top style='width:3.5in;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
  normal'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>Case
  1: 1 2<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
  normal'><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>Case
  2: 1 2 3 4<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>Case 3:
  1<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
  font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-family:Arial'>Problemsetter: Sohel Hafiz<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span

<style>
<!--

	mso-font-signature:-1610611985 1073750139 0 0 159 0;}
@font-face
	{font-family:"\@Arial Unicode MS";
	panose-1:2 11 6 4 2 2 2 2 2 4;
	mso-font-charset:128;
	mso-generic-font-family:swiss;
	mso-font-pitch:variable;
	mso-font-signature:-1 -369098753 63 0 4129279 0;}
 /* Style Definitions */
 p.MsoNormal, li.MsoNormal, div.MsoNormal
	{mso-style-parent:" ;
	margin:0in;
	margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:12.0pt;
	mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
